content.title: Fluid Responsiveness Assessment
content.summary: Fluid responsiveness refers to whether cardiac output will increase meaningfully (typically >10-15%) with fluid administration. Only about 50% of hypotensive ICU patients are fluid responsive. Predicting responsiveness before giving fluids is crucial because unnecessary fluids cause harm (pulmonary edema, organ dysfunction). Dynamic parameters (PPV, SVV, passive leg raise) outperform static measures (CVP) for prediction. The key physiologic concept is Frank-Starling: only patients on the steep portion of the curve will increase SV with preload increase.
key_points: Fluid responsive: Cardiac output increases ≥10-15% with volume
Only ~50% of hypotensive patients are fluid responsive
Static measures (CVP, PCWP) do NOT predict fluid responsiveness
PPV >13% or SVV >13% predicts responsiveness (in ventilated, Vt ≥8 mL/kg, sinus rhythm)
Passive leg raise: Non-invasive, reversible; works with arrhythmias and spontaneous breathing
Excessive fluids cause harm: pulmonary edema, delayed extubation, AKI
content.statement: Fluid responsiveness assessment determines whether a patient's cardiac output will increase with volume administration, using dynamic parameters like PPV and passive leg raise that outperform static measures like CVP, preventing harmful overresuscitation.

explanation.intuition: Think of the heart like a rubber band on a slingshot. If the band is already stretched tight (full heart), pulling it back more won't launch the projectile further. But if it's loose (empty heart), more stretch means more power. Dynamic parameters test whether the 'rubber band' has room to stretch.
explanation.key_insight: The Frank-Starling curve is the key concept. Patients on the flat portion won't increase cardiac output with fluids - they're already 'full'. Dynamic parameters exploit respiratory variation: if BP swings big with ventilator breaths, the heart is on the steep portion and will respond to fluids.
explanation.technical_details: PPV = (PPmax - PPmin) / PPmean × 100. Requirements for PPV/SVV: mechanical ventilation, Vt ≥8 mL/kg IBW, sinus rhythm, closed chest, no RV failure. PLR technique: from 45° semi-recumbent, lower trunk flat and raise legs to 45°; measure CO/SV change at 1 minute. Mini-fluid challenge: 100 mL over 1 minute; measure VTI change with echo.

definitions_glossary.fluid_responsiveness: Increase in cardiac output ≥10-15% with volume administration
definitions_glossary.Frank_Starling_curve: Relationship between preload and stroke volume
definitions_glossary.PPV: Pulse pressure variation; respiratory variation predicting fluid responsiveness
definitions_glossary.SVV: Stroke volume variation; similar to PPV
definitions_glossary.passive_leg_raise: PLR; autotransfusion test simulating fluid challenge
definitions_glossary.mini_fluid_challenge: Small bolus (100 mL) with immediate SV measurement
definitions_glossary.preload: End-diastolic volume/pressure; filling of the heart
definitions_glossary.fluid_overload: Excessive fluid causing edema and organ dysfunction
definitions_glossary.VTI: Velocity-time integral; echo measure of stroke volume
definitions_glossary.tidal_volume_challenge: Increasing Vt to amplify PPV for assessment

Frank_Starling.steep_portion: Low preload; SV increases significantly with volume
Frank_Starling.flat_portion: High preload; SV does not increase with volume
Frank_Starling.clinical_implication: Fluids help only on steep portion

heart_lung_interaction.in_responsive_patient: Large SV variation with respiratory cycle

CVP.evidence: Meta-analysis: no correlation with fluid responsiveness

PCWP.limitation: Same as CVP; does not predict response

IVC_diameter_variation.method: Ultrasound measurement of IVC collapse with breathing

technique: Lower trunk flat, raise legs to 45°
passive_leg_raise.measurement: Need real-time CO monitor (echo VTI, pulse contour, esophageal Doppler)

mini_fluid_challenge.advantage: Smaller volume than standard fluid challenge

end_expiratory_occlusion.mechanism: Increases venous return by stopping positive pressure

clinical_scenarios.can_use_PPV_SVV: Mechanical ventilation, Vt ≥8 mL/kg, sinus rhythm, closed chest
clinical_scenarios.cannot_use_PPV_SVV: Spontaneous breathing, arrhythmias, low Vt ventilation, open chest, severe RV failure

consequences_of_overresuscitation.AKI: Renal venous congestion impairs kidney function
consequences_of_overresuscitation.abdominal_compartment: Fluid in gut wall, intra-abdominal hypertension

definition.@value: Prediction of whether cardiac output will increase meaningfully with fluid administration

scopeNote.@value: Dynamic parameters (PPV, PLR) superior to static measures (CVP)

learning_objectives: Apply Frank-Starling physiology to fluid decisions
Calculate and interpret PPV and SVV
Perform passive leg raise test correctly
Identify when dynamic parameters are valid vs invalid
clinical_pearls: CVP does NOT predict fluid responsiveness - stop using it for this
PPV >13% or SVV >13% predicts response (if valid conditions met)
PLR is gold standard when PPV/SVV invalid (spontaneous breathing, arrhythmias)
Only ~50% of hypotensive patients are fluid responsive
Overresuscitation causes harm: pulmonary edema, AKI, longer ICU stay
common_misconceptions: Low CVP means give fluids - CVP doesn't predict response
All hypotensive patients need fluids - only half are responsive
PLR is less accurate than PPV - PLR works when PPV doesn't apply

citations.authors: Monnet X, Marik PE, Teboul JL
citations.title: Passive leg raising for predicting fluid responsiveness

evidence.confidence_rationale: Strong meta-analysis evidence for dynamic parameters
